A01:2021.name: Broken Access Control
A01:2021.description: Access control enforces policy such that users cannot act outside of their intended permissions. Failures typically lead to unauthorized information disclosure, modification, or destruction of data.
common_vulnerabilities: Bypassing access control checks by modifying the URL
Allowing the primary key to be changed to another user's record
Elevation of privilege (acting as admin when logged in as user)
CORS misconfiguration allowing unauthorized API access
Force browsing to authenticated pages as unauthenticated user
prevention: Deny by default, except for public resources
Implement access control mechanisms once and reuse throughout application
Model access controls should enforce record ownership
Disable web server directory listing
Log access control failures and alert admins
Rate limit API and controller access
Invalidate JWT tokens on server after logout
detection_patterns: Direct object references without ownership validation

A02:2021.name: Cryptographic Failures
A02:2021.description: Failures related to cryptography which often leads to sensitive data exposure. This includes data transmitted in clear text, use of weak cryptographic algorithms, and improper key management.
common_vulnerabilities: Transmitting data in clear text (HTTP, SMTP, FTP)
Not enforcing encryption via security headers
prevention: Classify data and apply controls per classification
Don't store sensitive data unnecessarily
Encrypt all sensitive data at rest
Use strong algorithms and proper key management
Encrypt data in transit with TLS 1.2+
Disable caching for sensitive data responses
Use password-specific hashing (Argon2, bcrypt, scrypt)

A03:2021.name: Injection
A03:2021.description: Injection flaws occur when untrusted data is sent to an interpreter as part of a command or query. The attacker's hostile data can trick the interpreter into executing unintended commands or accessing data without authorization.
prevention: Use parameterized queries and prepared statements
Use positive server-side input validation
Escape special characters for specific interpreters
Use LIMIT and other SQL controls to prevent mass disclosure
Use ORM frameworks with parameterized methods
Context-aware output encoding for XSS

A04:2021.name: Insecure Design
A04:2021.description: Insecure design represents different weaknesses, expressed as 'missing or ineffective control design.' It's not the source of all other Top 10 risk categories. Secure design requires threat modeling, secure design patterns, and reference architecture.
common_vulnerabilities: Missing rate limiting allowing brute force
prevention: Establish secure development lifecycle
Use threat modeling for authentication, access control, business logic
Integrate security language into user stories
Integrate plausibility checks at each tier
Write unit and integration tests for security controls
Segregate tenant separation at all tiers

A05:2021.name: Security Misconfiguration
A05:2021.description: The application might be vulnerable if it is missing appropriate security hardening or has improperly configured permissions on cloud services, unnecessary features are enabled, default accounts and passwords are unchanged.
common_vulnerabilities: Upgraded systems with insecure old configs
Security settings in frameworks not set to secure values
prevention: Repeatable hardening process for fast, secure deployment
Minimal platform without unnecessary features
Review and update configurations for security patches
Segmented application architecture
Send security directives to clients (Security Headers)
Automated verification of configurations

A06:2021.name: Vulnerable and Outdated Components
A06:2021.description: You are likely vulnerable if you do not know the versions of all components you use, if the software is vulnerable, unsupported, or out of date, if you do not fix or upgrade the underlying platform in a timely fashion.
A06:2021.prevalence: Supply chain attacks on the rise
common_vulnerabilities: Not knowing versions of all components (client and server-side)
Using vulnerable, unsupported, or out of date software
Not fixing or upgrading in a risk-based timely manner
Not testing compatibility of updated libraries
prevention: Remove unused dependencies, features, components
Continuously inventory versions of components
Only obtain components from official sources over secure links
Monitor for unmaintained libraries
Monitor for vulnerabilities in components (CVE, NVD)
Ensure ongoing plan for monitoring, triaging, applying updates
detection_patterns: Outdated package versions in lock files

A07:2021.name: Identification and Authentication Failures
A07:2021.description: Confirmation of the user's identity, authentication, and session management is critical to protect against authentication-related attacks.
common_vulnerabilities: Permitting automated attacks (credential stuffing, brute force)
Using plain text or weakly hashed passwords
Reusing session ID after successful login
prevention: Implement multi-factor authentication
Don't ship with default credentials
Implement weak password checks
Align password policies with NIST 800-63b
Harden against account enumeration attacks
Limit and delay failed login attempts
Use server-side, secure session manager
Invalidate sessions after logout, idle, and absolute timeouts

A08:2021.name: Software and Data Integrity Failures
A08:2021.description: Software and data integrity failures relate to code and infrastructure that does not protect against integrity violations. This includes using software from untrusted sources, CI/CD pipelines without integrity verification, and auto-update functionality without integrity checks.
common_vulnerabilities: Using libraries from untrusted CDNs or repositories
Insecure CI/CD pipeline allowing unauthorized code
prevention: Use digital signatures to verify software/data from expected source
Ensure libraries from trusted repositories
Use software supply chain security tool (OWASP Dependency-Check)
Ensure CI/CD pipeline has proper segregation and access control
Ensure unsigned/unencrypted serialized data is not sent to untrusted clients
Implement integrity checks on all serialized data

A09:2021.name: Security Logging and Monitoring Failures
A09:2021.description: Without logging and monitoring, breaches cannot be detected. Insufficient logging, detection, monitoring, and active response occurs any time.
common_vulnerabilities: Auditable events not logged (logins, failed logins, high-value transactions)
Warnings and errors generate no, inadequate, or unclear log messages
Logs not monitored for suspicious activity
Alerting thresholds and response escalation not effective
Penetration testing and DAST scans don't trigger alerts
Application cannot detect, escalate, or alert for attacks in real time
prevention: Log all login, access control, and server-side input validation failures
Ensure logs are in format easily consumed by log management solutions
Ensure high-value transactions have audit trail with integrity controls
Establish effective monitoring and alerting for suspicious activity
Establish or adopt incident response and recovery plan
detection_patterns: No audit trail for sensitive operations
Logs written with user input (log injection)

A10:2021.name: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
A10:2021.description: SSRF flaws occur whenever a web application is fetching a remote resource without validating the user-supplied URL. It allows an attacker to coerce the application to send a crafted request to an unexpected destination.
common_vulnerabilities: Fetching URL from user input without validation
Allowing access to internal services via URL manipulation
Reading local files via file:// scheme
Scanning internal ports via URL requests
prevention: Segment remote resource access in separate networks
Enforce 'deny by default' firewall policies
Sanitize and validate all client-supplied input data
Do not send raw responses to clients
Disable HTTP redirections
Be aware of URL consistency to avoid DNS rebinding
detection_patterns: User input passed to HTTP client libraries
